Kirk, I think that's a very interesting potential application area.  
Let m=
e make sure I'm understanding how it would work.  You are saying
that you m=
ight capture the shape of a protein binding region (or some
other important=
 region) with a CPPN and then use that CPPN-encoded
model to test other che=
mical compounds?  

But if you already have a model of the intended shape, =
what additional
capability would the CPPN provide other than encoding the 3=
D model
that you already have?  Or do you mean you might try creating new
s=
hapes with the CPPN that you haven't thought of and see how they
react with=
 known compounds?  There are probably other ways it could go
as well, but I=
'm curious from the point of view of computational
chemistry where the most=
 exciting opportunity would be.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "newtw=
ist2000" <rkdelisle@...> wrote:
>
> I may be over-interpreting the CPPN pro=
cess, but it stimulated a few
> ideas.  I work in the field of Computationa=
l Chemistry and my in my
> day to day operations I deal with drug-like chem=
ical compounds.  The
> 3D shape of a chemical is a principle determining fa=
ctor of its
> activity.  On top of 3D shape, you have different functional =
groups
> that impart different properties.  For example, let's say the shap=
e is
> just right to bind to a particular enzyme (and prevent it from runni=
ng
> amok) but you need an oxygen atom at a particular location, or a
> nit=
rogen, or any atom with a hydrogen attached, etc.
> 
> There are two ways t=
o get to this type of information.  First is
> having a large collection of=
 chemicals with a known endpoint.  For
> this I usually apply the standard =
pattern recognition tools.  Another
> more difficult approach is when you d=
on't have much data for
> chemicals, but you know the 3D structure of the e=
nzyme and where you
> want your chemical to bind.  I'm wondering if there i=
s an application
> for CPPNs here.  Can the CPPN capture the shape of the s=
ite along with
> the essential properties based on the protein itself and t=
hen be used
> to assess different chemical compounds that have not yet been=
 tested -
> try to predict their activities.
> 
> Any thoughts??
> 
> -Kirk=

> 
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrot=
e:
> >
> > Kirk, what is your idea for applying CPPNs to pattern recognitio=
n?  I
> > am not sure I followed exactly how the CPPN would be connected to=
 the
> > neural network?
> > 
> > As Peter mentioned, we have used the idea=
 of CPPNs to represent
> > connectivity patterns rather than the spatial pa=
tterns you saw in the
> > CPPN paper.  These connectivity patterns can then=
 be interpreted of
> > neural network connectivity patterns, which means yo=
u can evolve
> > neural networks with regularities in their connectivities.=
  There are
> > currently four papers on this approach to evolving ANNs wit=
h CPPNs,
> > which is called HyperNEAT.  Those papers are available from my=

homepage
> > 
> > http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/
> > 
> > or from EPlex =
publications:
> > 
> > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications.html
> > 
> > T=
he particular papers are:
> > 
> > -A Novel Generative Encoding for Exploit=
ing Neural Network Sensor and 
> > Output Geometry
> > 
> > -Generating Lar=
ge-Scale Neural Networks Through Discovering Geometric
> > Regularities 
> =
> 
> > -A Case Study on the Critical Role of Geometric Regularity in Machin=
e
> > Learning
> > 
> > -Generative Encoding for Multiagent Learning 
> > 
=
> > A longer journal paper on HyperNEAT is also forthcoming in Artificial
>=
 > Life journal.
> > 
> > By the way, you can also interactively evolve you=
r own CPPNs images
> > online at http://picbreeder.org
> > 
> > Because spa=
tial patterns and connectivity patterns can represent just
> > about anythi=
ng, there are other potential applications of CPPNs beyond
> > representing=
 ANNs, but currently there is no publication of such an
> > application tha=
t I know of.  But it would be interesting to see more
> > work in that dire=
ction.
> > 
> > ken 
> > 
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_cher=
venski" <petar_chervenski@>
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > HyperNEAT uses CPPNs to =
build the neural network phenotypes (and 
> > > evolves CPPNs). I see this =
as an extension. There are about 3 or
more 
> > > papers on HyperNEAT. It s=
hould be interesting to you, though it is
> just 
> > > one of all possible=
 applications. 
> > > 
> > > Peter
> > >

, "newtwist2000" <rkdelisle@> wrote:

 the paper Compositional Pattern Producing
> > > > Networks: A Novel Abstra=
ction of Development - very interesting
> stuff.
> > > >  
> > > > Are ther=
e additional papers that extend on this?  Currently
what I'm
> > > > seeing=
 is based on visual representations, but are there papers
> where
> > > > t=
his has been extended to pattern recognition or other fields?  My
> > > > t=
hought is that if a CPPN can capture important spatial
details that
> > > >=
 can then be evaluated by a standard NN, can the two improve on
> pattern
>=
 > > > recognition tasks that have a relative spatial component -

opological, geometric, higher dimensions...
